scenes.voiceover_script: Ever wonder why your savings account suddenly pays more interest, or why mortgage rates keep changing? It's not random. Behind the scenes, the government has two powerful levers that control how money flows through the entire economy and, ultimately, into your pocket.
scenes.h2_heading: Why Your Interest Rates Keep Changing

scenes.voiceover_script: The government manages the economy using two main tools. First, monetary policy, run by the Federal Reserve, controls interest rates and money supply. Second, fiscal policy, managed by Congress, controls government spending and taxes. Think of them as the gas pedal and brake for the entire economy.
scenes.h2_heading: The Two Levers: Monetary and Fiscal Policy

scenes.voiceover_script: Here's what's happening right now: the Fed projects rates around 3.4% through 2026, down from recent highs. Meanwhile, the federal deficit is expected to hit 1.7 trillion dollars in 2026. These numbers directly affect your mortgage rates, loan costs, and even your job security. Understanding them isn't optionalâ€”it's essential.

If you have a mortgage, carry any debt, invest in stocks, or simply want job security, these policies affect you daily. When the Fed cuts rates, borrowing gets cheaper. When government spending rises, certain sectors boom. Either way, you're playing in their game.

Here's your action plan: First, follow Fed announcements, they happen eight times a year and signal rate direction. Second, consider locking in fixed rates when cuts are expected. Third, understand which sectors benefit from government spending, like infrastructure and defense. Knowledge of these trends gives you an edge.
Want to stay ahead of economic shifts? Subscribe to MoneyWise for weekly updates on how policy changes affect your finances. Knowledge is your best investment.
